data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A bulbous Mediterranean plant (Hyacinthus orientalis) having narrow leaves and a terminal raceme of variously colored, usually fragrant flowers, with a funnel-shaped perianth.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: Any of several similar or related plants, such as the grape hyacinth.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A plant, perhaps the larkspur, gladiolus, or iris, that sprang from the blood of the slain Hyacinthus.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A deep purplish blue to vivid violet.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A reddish or cinnamon-colored variety of transparent zircon, used as a gemstone.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A blue precious stone, perhaps the sapphire, known in antiquity.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: An ornamental bulbous plant of the genus Hyacinthus (H. orientalis), natural order Liliaceæ.
By transfer, a plant of some other genus.
